name: market for hard coal | hard coal | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/8690/documentation

This is a market activity. Each market represents the consumption mix of a product in a given geography, connecting suppliers with consumers of the same product in the same geographical area. Markets group the producers and also the imports of the product (if relevant) within the same geographical area. They also account for transport to the consumer and for the losses during that process, when relevant.;This is the market for  'hard coal', in the geography of Northern America.;This dataset covers the average transport distance specific to the domestic market of hard coal in North America (US and Canada). All inland transportation modes are used for coal shipments in this region. In the US, which is the dominating coal market in North America, about 70% of coal is transported by rail, about 10% by barges on inland waterways, 10% by truck and 10% by conveyor belts to reach its destination of use or exporting ports (Association of American Railroads, 2017). Dust from transport and load/unload operations is included. Average coal losses are considered. Average emissions to water due to leaching from coal heaps at storage are estimated based on literature.;Reference(s):;Association of American Railroads. 2017. Railroads and Coal. Accessed online at: https://www.aar.org/BackgroundPapers/Railroads%20and%20Coal.pdf, 13 November 2017.;hard coal' is a fossil fuel with a calorific value of 27.91 MJ/kg. It is used as a solid fuel and is sourced from coal mines after crushing, screening and washing the coal. Its main applications are in the following sectors: domestic fuel (mainly for hand-fired stoves), as filter media and as an ingredient in charcoal briquettes.

This activity starts at the hard coal preparation plant with the beneficiated coal ready to be loaded on rail, truck, barge or conveyor.

activity end: The activity ends with the unloading of hard coal at domestic consumers or export hubs.
category: B:Mining and quarrying/05:Mining of coal and lignite/051:Mining of hard coal/0510:Mining of hard coal

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Transport distances are geography specific, losses and related emissions are generic values applicable worldwide.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Transport data geography specific, emissions, losses, energy and land requirements are generic assumptions.

exchanges.description: EcoSpold01Location=WEU

flow.name: hard coal
flow.category: B:Mining and quarrying/05:Mining of coal and lignite/051:Mining of hard coal/0510:Mining of hard coal

exchanges.description:
An average distance for coal transports via inland waterways in North America is assumed to be 300km. About 10% of coal in the US gets transported by barge according to the Association of American Railroads (2017), this is assumed for the entire Region North America.
Reference(s): 
Association of American Railroads. 2017. Railroads and Coal. Accessed online at: https://www.aar.org/BackgroundPapers/Railroads%20and%20Coal.pdf, 13 November 2017.

exchanges.description: Assumption by Dones, R., Bauer, C., Röder, A. (2007) Kohle. In: Dones, R. (Ed.) et al., Sachbilanzen von Energiesystemen: Grundlagen für den ökologischen Vergleich von Energiesystemen und den Einbezug von Energiesystemen in Ökobilanzen für die Schweiz. Final report ecoinvent No. 6-VI, Paul Scherrer Institut Villigen, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.

An average distance for coal transports via conveyor belt in North America is assumed to be 15km. About 10% of coal in the US gets transported by conveyor (mostly in the case of minemouth plants) according to the Association of American Railroads (2017), this is assumed for the entire Region North America.
Reference(s): 
Association of American Railroads. 2017. Railroads and Coal. Accessed online at: https://www.aar.org/BackgroundPapers/Railroads%20and%20Coal.pdf, 13 November 2017.

exchanges.description:
Average distance of coal transports by truck in the US in 2004 according to the National Research Council (2007) is 50km. About 10% of coal in the US gets transported by truck according to the Association of American Railroads (2017).
Reference(s): 
National Research Council. 2007. Coal: Research and Development to Support National Energy Policy. Washington, DC: The National Academies Press. https://doi.org/10.17226/11977. Accessed online at: https://www.nap.edu/read/11977/chapter/7#81, 13 November 2017.
Association of American Railroads. 2017. Railroads and Coal. Accessed online at: https://www.aar.org/BackgroundPapers/Railroads%20and%20Coal.pdf, 13 November 2017.

exchanges.description: Assumption by Dones, R., Bauer, C., Röder, A. (2007) Kohle. In: Dones, R. (Ed.) et al., Sachbilanzen von Energiesystemen: Grundlagen für den ökologischen Vergleich von Energiesystemen und den Einbezug von Energiesystemen in Ökobilanzen für die Schweiz. Final report ecoinvent No. 6-VI, Paul Scherrer Institut Villigen, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.

Assumption by Dones et al.: per one time of unloading from transport mode, (storing) and loading on subsequent transport mode an average demand (electric) energy of 7.2 kWh/tonne and an average land use demand of 1m2*a/tonne is required.
Reference(s):
Dones, R., Bauer, C., Röder, A. (2007) Kohle. In: Dones, R. (Ed.) et al., Sachbilanzen von Energiesystemen: Grundlagen für den ökologischen Vergleich von Energiesystemen und den Einbezug von Energiesystemen in Ökobilanzen für die Schweiz. Final report ecoinvent No. 6-VI, Paul Scherrer Institut Villigen, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.

Averge transport distance of hard coal by rail in 2014 in the US was 867 miles (about 1400km) according to the Association of American Railroads (2017). The share of rail transport in total coal transports in the US is about 70%. The resulting value for the US is extrapolated to the entire geography Region North America.
Reference(s): 
National Research Council. 2007. Coal: Research and Development to Support National Energy Policy. Washington, DC: The National Academies Press. https://doi.org/10.17226/11977. Accessed online at: https://www.nap.edu/read/11977/chapter/7#81, 13 November 2017.
Association of American Railroads. 2017. Railroads and Coal. Accessed online at: https://www.aar.org/BackgroundPapers/Railroads%20and%20Coal.pdf, 13 November 2017.
